questions.question_text: Which type of zone will allow different virtual systems to communicate with each other?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
External zones are required to allow traffic between zones in different virtual systems, without the traffic leaving the firewall.

Selected Answer: D
A,B, and C are interface types not "Zone".

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D, external

Selected Answer: D
D. External
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/virtual-systems/communication-between-virtual-systems/inter-vsys-traffic-that-remains-within-the-firewall/external-zone

D is correct

questions.question_text:
An organization is interested in migrating from their existing web proxy architecture to the Web Proxy feature of their PAN-OS 11.0 firewalls. Currently, HTTP and SSL requests contain the destination IP address of the web server and the client browser is redirected to the proxy.

Which PAN-OS proxy method should be configured to maintain this type of traffic flow?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Destination ip is proxy means explicit.
Destination ip is server means transparent

comments.content:
Wont the proxy server always do a redirection, even if the destination IP is the original webserver? A debug should reveal a 301 move, especially if the request is the server IP address. 
I think the key is the browser configuration which is redirected to proxy. I think answer is B, though the question was meant to confuse readers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
For the transparent proxy method, the request contains the destination IP address of the web server and the proxy transparently intercepts the client request (either by being in-line or by traffic steering). There is no client configuration and Panorama is optional. Transparent proxy requires a loopback interface, User-ID configuration in the proxy zone, and specific Destination NAT (DNAT) rules. Transparent proxy does not support X-Authenticated Users (XAU) or Web Cache Communications Protocol (WCCP).
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-new-features/networking-features/web-proxy

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-new-features/networking-features/web-proxy

Selected Answer: C
For the transparent proxy method, the request contains the destination IP address of the web server and the proxy transparently intercepts the client request (either by being in-line or by traffic steering)

Selected Answer: C
Bros, at first (and I remember I got this question on the exam, took it on August 13th 2024 - 2nd failure). 

In explicit proxy, you would send the traffic explicitly to the web proxy, this means, that you'd be aware of the web proxy connection. However, this question states that the petition is sent to the web server (not proxy). The web browser transparently sends the petition to the proxy and there you go.

Selected Answer: B
the client browser is explicitly configured

Selected Answer: C
C - Transparent 
For the transparent proxy method, the request contains the destination IP address of the WEB SERVER

Selected Answer: B
3.6.2 Explicit proxy
For the explicit proxy method, the request contains the destination IP address of the configured proxy and the client browser sends requests to the proxy directly

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. "destination IP address of the web server"
This question was on the exam.. Nov 2023

Selected Answer: C
C: As per samqq's reference : For the transparent proxy method, the request contains the destination IP address of the web server and the proxy transparently intercepts the client request (either by being in-line or by traffic steering). There is no client configuration and Panorama is optional. Transparent proxy requires a loopback interface, User-ID configuration in the proxy zone, and specific Destination NAT (DNAT) rules. Transparent proxy does not support X-Authenticated Users (XAU) or Web Cache Communications Protocol (WCCP).
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-new-features/networking-features/web-proxy

Selected Answer: B
client browser is redirected to the proxy...mean it use pas file so explicit proxy if you ti maintain this type of traffic flow
B. Explicit proxy.

questions.question_text:
An engineer discovers the management interface is not routable to the User-ID agent.

What configuration is needed to allow the firewall to communicate to the User-ID agent?

choices.D: Add a static route to the virtual router
choices.A: Add a Policy Based Forwarding (PBF) policy to the User-ID agent IP
choices.B: Create a NAT policy for the User-ID agent server
choices.C: Create a custom service route for the UID Agent

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

C

https://live.paloaltonetworks.com/t5/blogs/accessing-uid-agent-or-ad-when-your-management-interface-is-oob/ba-p/524595

Selected Answer: C
C seems correct

Selected Answer: D
Run the following commands to disable the option permanently:

> configure

# set deviceconfig setting session tcp-reject-non-syn no

# commit

------

B, would be correct if it would be set to NO.

Run the following commands to disable TCP reject non-SYN temporarily (until reboot)

> set session tcp-reject-non-syn no

source:https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClEwCAK

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Selected Answer: D
It's D.

B is almost correct... but it would be "no" not "yes". In troubleshooting, I would use this option because it's temporary... D would be permanent. However, the only correct option is D.

https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClEwCAK

comments.content: If B was set session tcp-reject-non-syn no this would be correct. Since it's "yes" it's not correct. D is the only correct answer.

discussion.content: B. set session tcp-reject-non-syn yes

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D. Refer to samqq's link.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is d. a makes no sense at all

Selected Answer: D
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClEwCAK

questions.question_text:
An engineer receives reports from users that applications are not working and that websites are only partially loading in an asymmetric environment. After investigating, the engineer observes the flow_tcp_non_syn_drop counter increasing in the show counters global output.

Which troubleshooting command should the engineer use to work around this issue?

choices.A: set deviceconfig setting tcp asymmetric-path drop
choices.D: set deviceconfig setting session tcp-reject-non-syn no
choices.C: set deviceconfig setting tcp asymmetric-path bypass

questions.question_text: Where is Palo Alto Networks Device Telemetry data stored on a firewall with a device certificate installed?

choices.D: On Palo Alto Networks Update Servers

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Device telemetry collects data about your next-generation firewall or Panorama and shares it with Palo Alto Networks by uploading the data to Cortex Data Lake. This data is used to power telemetry apps, which are cloud-based applications that make it easy to monitor and manage your next-generation firewalls and Panoramas.

source: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/device-telemetry/device-telemetry-overview

PS a side note, for future use: iff your organization does not have a Cortex Data Lake license, then you must install a device certificate in order to share this data. -- so there are 2 options in case this ever comes up in the exam or in your job.

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer is C

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/device-telemetry/device-telemetry-overview

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
